UI_visible_response: "Under the Dome" is a work of very broad, very black social satire, and it ought to be read in that context. The individual characters don't seem to matter very much in this context1. Additionally, "Under the Dome" is a thriller about a small town suddenly and inexplicably sealed off from the rest of the world by an enormous transparent dome, which serves as a microcosm of society and provides a profound examination of how individuals and communities respond to an unprecedented crisis4. It also manages to be a domestic drama, a disaster film, and a horror-filled science-fiction tale rolled into one, with some romance, humor, and pathos3. Furthermore, it is noted for exploring the dark side of humans in captivity7.
